commit_message:
Add an 'always' tag to cluster layout task include

The templates which generate the configuration for the various
components require access to the facts defining the cluster layout.

Running the setup*.yml playbooks with --tags config would not include
common_task_data_node_hosts.yml and templating would fail due to
undefined vars.

This change applys an 'always' tag to all uses of the include.

Change-Id: I6c55a60aef54f9bb26eb9a2af08315265daa82d9

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 19:06:49.000000000', 'message': "Adds support for leaping from Mitaka

Adds a few tweaks to get Mitaka to function as a
leapfrog source.

- Adds Mitaka as option
- Adjusts detection to include eol branches
- Creates file if user_variables.yml doesn't exist
- Checks if osa_secrets_file_name exists

Change-Id: Id0bce1441456bc545deca67710004b750901e81b
"}]
commit_message:
Adds support for leaping from Mitaka

Adds a few tweaks to get Mitaka to function as a
leapfrog source.

- Adds Mitaka as option
- Adjusts detection to include eol branches
- Creates file if user_variables.yml doesn't exist
- Checks if osa_secrets_file_name exists

Change-Id: Id0bce1441456bc545deca67710004b750901e81b

subject: Correct elasticsearch host roles for small clusters
messages: [{'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-06-19 10:31:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-20 15:01:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-19 10:31:11.000000000', 'message': 'Correct elasticsearch host roles for small clusters

Previously, the number of masters was equal to the node count divided
by two and rounded up if an even number. This worked for cluster sizes
greater than 3 nodes but did not properly assign enough masters for a
3 node cluster, and did not handle special cases of single node clusters
that may exist in a test environment.

New code handles these edge cases and improves the comments around node
role assignment.

Correcting the number of masters has the side effect of also correcting
the layout of data nodes. A 3 node cluster will no longer exhibit an
unused node.

Change-Id: I2243a6c0163ab32e3c0def383a10244a34450530
'}]
commit_message:
Correct elasticsearch host roles for small clusters

Previously, the number of masters was equal to the node count divided
by two and rounded up if an even number. This worked for cluster sizes
greater than 3 nodes but did not properly assign enough masters for a
3 node cluster, and did not handle special cases of single node clusters
that may exist in a test environment.

New code handles these edge cases and improves the comments around node
role assignment.

Correcting the number of masters has the side effect of also correcting
the layout of data nodes. A 3 node cluster will no longer exhibit an
unused node.

Change-Id: I2243a6c0163ab32e3c0def383a10244a34450530

subject: Add explicit enable=true when a check is enabled
messages: [{'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-16 04:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22405, 'date': '2018-06-16 13:53:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-20 14:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-16 04:46:01.000000000', 'message': 'Add explicit enable=true when a check is enabled

Some checks have a default of "enabled" true when the config is present
and loaded, others have a default of false. This change sets
"enable=true" explicitly which will ensure we're turning on all of the
checks we expect without any surprises.

Change-Id: I268b045906a19c63ad698c348204e8cbe3a93361
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add explicit enable=true when a check is enabled

Some checks have a default of "enabled" true when the config is present
and loaded, others have a default of false. This change sets
"enable=true" explicitly which will ensure we're turning on all of the
checks we expect without any surprises.

Change-Id: I268b045906a19c63ad698c348204e8cbe3a93361
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add Fast Forward Upgrade docs

Reusing the same content of the OSP12 -> 13 documentation, but
specifically adapting the content to cover Fast Forward Upgrades.

Co-Authored-By: Yolanda Robla <yroblamo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I337daf8c722d77190dc473540e445e3a1f515bf9

subject: Castellan-compatible key store is a base service
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 7973, 'name': 'Douglas Mendizábal', 'email': 'dmendiza@redhat.com', 'username': 'dougmendizabal'}, {'_account_id': 8866, 'name': 'Raildo Mascena de Sousa Filho', 'email': 'rmascena@redhat.com', 'username': 'raildo'}, {'_account_id': 9237, 'name': 'Kevin Fox', 'email': 'kevin@efox.cc', 'username': 'kfox1111'}, {'_account_id': 9914, 'name': 'Ade Lee', 'email': 'alee@redhat.com', 'username': 'alee'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28223, 'name': 'Cedric Jeanneret', 'display_name': 'cjeanner (Tengu)', 'email': 'cjeanner@redhat.com', 'username': 'cjeanner'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-06 01:28:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2018-06-06 05:31:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-06-06 08:11:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-06 09:54:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with the intent here, as adding a proper secret store to base services is the only way to send the signal that reinventing secrets storage locally in every project is the worst idea in the world.

My initial concern here is that a number of projects depend on barbican directly, using features that are not available from any Castellan-compatible key storage... So the statement here may put our users in a weird corner -- they select Vault as their Castellan-compatible key storage, only to discover they need to switch to Barbican in the future when they add a component which depends on Barbican.

But it appears that Barbican can now be backed by Vault, so I guess there is still a valid migration path there. So the only reason we would consider adding Barbican directly to base services (instead of any Castellan-compatible solution) would be if we expected most projects to depend on Barbican-specific features in the end. 

Do we have a clear idea of which component would end up leveraging castellan vs. barbican ? Should we do this quick analysis first ?'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-06 13:59:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My concern is that explicitly putting a user-facing API in the base services list could be an end-run around the Interoperability effort with trademark programs. Basically we'd be claiming that API is a guaranteed part of an OpenStack deployment, similar to how Keystone is treated.

Security operations advocacy hat on, I'm all for the idea. Practically speaking though, it seems like a much larger conversation than this (which is still a step in the right direction, if not as grand in scope)."}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2018-06-06 15:49:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-06 16:07:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

> But it appears that Barbican can now be backed by Vault, so I guess there is still a valid migration path there.

And apparently that's implemented via Castellan: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-05-31.log.html#t2018-05-31T16:52:43

So in theory migration should be trivial.

> So the only reason we would consider adding Barbican directly to base services (instead of any Castellan-compatible solution) would be if we expected most projects to depend on Barbican-specific features in the end.

I agree with Jeremy that adding Barbican to base services would be weird. I think if we want it to always be available, we should be doing that through other means (constellations; the trademark program).

Incidentally, I *do* think we want it to always be available, and we should start pursuing that through those other means.

This seems like a reasonable first step though. It'll encourage some folks to install Barbican, and the rest who install Vault will at least have a backend for Barbican already available, so it lowers the hurdle to eventually deploying it.

I would like to see us state somewhere that we don't want every project to effectively reimplement the Barbican API when they need to get secrets from a user to Castellan, and instead require Barbican for those features. I don't know that this is the right place to do that though."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-06 16:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> > But it appears that Barbican can now be backed by Vault, so I
 > guess there is still a valid migration path there.
 > 
 > And apparently that's implemented via Castellan: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-05-31.log.html#t2018-05-31T16:52:43
 > 
 > So in theory migration should be trivial.
 > 
 > > So the only reason we would consider adding Barbican directly to
 > base services (instead of any Castellan-compatible solution) would
 > be if we expected most projects to depend on Barbican-specific
 > features in the end.
 > 
 > I agree with Jeremy that adding Barbican to base services would be
 > weird. I think if we want it to always be available, we should be
 > doing that through other means (constellations; the trademark
 > program).

The team managing the trademark programs has consistently taken the view that their definitions for trademarks should trail development and deployment. So waiting until they add barbican isn't going to help us support teams who want to rely on it now.

We're perfectly within our mandate to set the "future technical direction" for the trademark folks by specifying, in some form, that project teams are allowed to build features that rely on the presence of any other OpenStack component. That sort of statement also fits into our role leading the overall technical implementation of those projects.

 > 
 > Incidentally, I *do* think we want it to always be available, and
 > we should start pursuing that through those other means.
 > 
 > This seems like a reasonable first step though. It'll encourage
 > some folks to install Barbican, and the rest who install Vault will
 > at least have a backend for Barbican already available, so it
 > lowers the hurdle to eventually deploying it.
 > 
 > I would like to see us state somewhere that we don't want every
 > project to effectively reimplement the Barbican API when they need
 > to get secrets from a user to Castellan, and instead require
 > Barbican for those features. I don't know that this is the right
 > place to do that though.

Yes, that's my main concern with limiting this to castellan. We have 2 sets of features. Some will work without exposing secrets to users (or asking users to provide them). Others will require APIs for managing secrets. We want services to use barbican for those features, so that interacting with two clouds that have the feature will be consistent. The alternative is that in one cloud a user would have to talk to Vault and then OpenStack, but in another they would have to talk to Custodia before OpenStack. That means the overall workflow isn't interoperable. We've already had the trademark team reject some aspects of the new image upload API because there are multiple ways to interact with it, and that's just within an OpenStack component.

So, yes, this is a good first step. But we need to acknowledge that it is only going to take us part of the way to where we want to be and I think we should do that within the body of this change. I've proposed some very rough wording for that inline.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-06 16:44:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm fine with the additional wording, just concerned because the last year of discussions and the entire reason Castellan came into being was because there was pushback on care and feeding for yet another mandatory API service. I'm worried that if we make this change about requiring Barbican as a user-facing API in all deployments, then we'll never get consensus from the community as it's a complete reversal of what I gathered from the notes on the many previous discussions.

Saying that services can rely on a control-plane key store with a standardized interface is an improvement over the status quo, so would rather not delay expressing that in our base services list while we work on getting community buy-in for being able to expect that a new user-facing secrets management API will be standard in all future interoperable OpenStack deployments."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-07 12:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-10 21:45:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2018-06-11 13:35:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-11 14:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-11 14:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-11 14:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-11 14:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-11 14:55:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-11 15:10:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-12 08:30:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

It's also worth reminding here that "base services" is guidance for developers, not deployers. It's a hard call for developers to rely on external features, as it creates a burden on operators, and who are they to make that call ? This document is the TC's way of saying: "in that specific case, you should consider this is OK".

So basically, this change is saying that developers should definitely add features that leverage properly-stored secrets through Castellan. It's not really about urging operators to deploy a particular secrets store, so I'm not sure we need to add anything more in terms of which backend to deploy.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-06-12 12:23:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:14:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> It's also worth reminding here that "base services" is guidance for
 > developers, not deployers. It's a hard call for developers to rely
 > on external features, as it creates a burden on operators, and who
 > are they to make that call ? This document is the TC's way of
 > saying: "in that specific case, you should consider this is OK".
 > 
 > So basically, this change is saying that developers should
 > definitely add features that leverage properly-stored secrets
 > through Castellan. It's not really about urging operators to deploy
 > a particular secrets store, so I'm not sure we need to add anything
 > more in terms of which backend to deploy.

Yes, I agree, but it's the developers I want to guide here. I want them to not build proxy APIs, and now that Jeremy has helped me understand that's what I want I think we should just say that. Maybe something like:

  Projects should not build proxy APIs that rely on Castellan to talk to a key store
  and let users manage keys.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:23:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Perhaps something more along the lines of: "Castellan is intended to provide an interface for services to interact with a key store, but should not be treated as a means to proxy API calls from users to that key store. In order to reduce unnecessary exposure risks, any user-facing handling of secret material should be left to a dedicated API (preferably as provided by Barbican)."'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:33:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Perhaps something more along the lines of: "Castellan is intended 
> to provide an interface for services to interact with a key store,
> but should not be treated as a means to proxy API calls from users
> to that key store. In order to reduce unnecessary exposure risks,
> any user-facing handling of secret material should be left to a
> dedicated API (preferably as provided by Barbican)."

I like that.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:43:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think we can and should make this a bit less ambiguous.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:44:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Perhaps something more along the lines of: "Castellan is intended
 > to provide an interface for services to interact with a key store,
 > but should not be treated as a means to proxy API calls from users
 > to that key store. In order to reduce unnecessary exposure risks,
 > any user-facing handling of secret material should be left to a
 > dedicated API (preferably as provided by Barbican)."

+1'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2018-06-13 16:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So, just requesting clarification:

1. For volume encryption, cinder uses castellan to generate an encryption key in a key store on behalf of a user.  Nova uses castellan to retrieve it.  This is all OK because none of this exposes secret management to the user.

2. https://github.com/openstack/castellan-ui creates a horizon plugin to allow users to manage their secrets.  This is NOT OK because its using castellan as proxy API for users to manage their secrets directly?  What would be OK would be a barbican-ui that uses barbican API to access secrets.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-13 16:28:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ade: Yes, that's precisely what I'm attempting to convey. If you agree that my proposed modification accurately reflects the acceptability/unacceptability in your examples, then I'll go ahead and add it in a new patchset."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-13 16:45:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> So, just requesting clarification:
 > 
 > 1. For volume encryption, cinder uses castellan to generate an
 > encryption key in a key store on behalf of a user.  Nova uses
 > castellan to retrieve it.  This is all OK because none of this
 > exposes secret management to the user.

Yes.

 > 2. https://github.com/openstack/castellan-ui creates a horizon
 > plugin to allow users to manage their secrets.  This is NOT OK
 > because its using castellan as proxy API for users to manage their
 > secrets directly?  What would be OK would be a barbican-ui that
 > uses barbican API to access secrets.

Yes. And this is also not desirable because it requires someone who wants to interact with the secret store in that cloud to use castellan from their client or to know what the secret store API is, rather than being able to use keystone's service catalog to discover that barbican is present."}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2018-06-13 17:09:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sounds good to me then.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2018-06-13 18:47:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree on clarifications for 1. and 2.  I'd also like to see some examples of features that would require Barbican instead of Castellan including:

* User interaction with the secret in any way including upload, retrieval or deletion.
* User ownership of the secret.  While somewhat related to the previous point, it should be pointed out that storing secrets via Castellan would result in the secret being owned by the service.
* Bundling of separate secrets into a single entity.  e.g. Barbican Containers."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-13 18:52:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We've kept the other entries in the base services list fairly brief. Do we want to add a separate paragraph or two with detailed guidance on this one, or trust that developers can make sane distinctions between what is and isn't a proxy API?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-13 19:05:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> We've kept the other entries in the base services list fairly
 > brief. Do we want to add a separate paragraph or two with detailed
 > guidance on this one, or trust that developers can make sane
 > distinctions between what is and isn't a proxy API?

Let's keep it brief."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-13 19:56:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

+1 for Jeremy's latest suggestion."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:52:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote-1

LGTM!'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-06-14 14:53:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2018-06-14 15:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-14 16:48:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-14 16:53:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-15 09:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-15 12:20:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2018-06-15 14:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-06-18 16:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2018-06-19 12:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-06-20 10:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

commit_message:
Castellan-compatible key store is a base service

Per the past year of discussions, culminating in the most recent
mailing list thread[*], it's apparent that providing a consistent
solution for storage of key material and similar secrets by security
features of various OpenStack services is in the best interests of
the project. By providing this guarantee in the base services set,
projects don't need to worry about implementing insecure fallback
alternatives or needlessly duplicating functionality to cope with
the lack of an already-available solution.

[*] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130567.html

Change-Id: Ia46211f41726d5671bf28a632d17fc56965b6fcc

commit_message:
Fix pep8 new warnings and pip install error

This patch is a squash of two fix that are needed together to have a
successful zuul run.

1. pep8 fix (cherry-picked from master:
   87eb1b15be8a4e39f3344f829d1a5b295a37a858 )

A recent change in pep/pycodingchecks introduced new warnings as part of
the pep8 target that causes pep8 to fail now.

This patch fixes code that issued warnings W503,E731,E266,E402

In addition, old tests which were not ran anyway, and are no longer
relevant (test_firewall) were deleted.

Conflicts:
	neutron_fwaas/tests/tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/manager.py

2. Avoid parameterless pip install

build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs fail on all stable branches due to the
new pip version 10 introduces some previously Warning as Error: in case
of calling "pip install" without any package name, the command fails.
tox_install.sh is called during docs job without any package passed to
pip.

This patch also disables E402 hacking check because releasenotes/* violates it
(the issue is not present in Queens+ where
Ib19f7ea4ea136180f38bc78389f51b6b5d179ab8 is merged).

Conflicts:
      neutron_fwaas/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/queens/expand/876782258a43_create_default_firewall_groups_table.py
      neutron_fwaas/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/queens/expand/f24e0d5e5bff_uniq_firewallgroupportassociation0port.py
      neutron_fwaas/services/firewall/fwaas_plugin_v2.py
      neutron_fwaas/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/pike/contract/fd38cd995cc0_shared_attribute_for_firewall_resources.py
      neutron_fwaas/tests/unit/extensions/test_firewall.py
      tox.ini

Change-Id: If893cf2bc136d09e09344a81fd996ac89479a135
(cherry picked from commit 58a62382e939b47d7bb75e985852aa214f9f3cdd)
(cherry picked from commit 1d884eab72375af862d50045acc2aa7b62985207)

commit_message:
Remove PyPI downloads

According to official site,
https://packaging.python.org/guides/analyzing-pypi-package-downloads/
PyPI package download statistics is no longer maintained and thus
should be removed.

Change-Id: I4b5ac033e57f486d710c394a51e012fa8adabab3

commit_message:
WIP: Enable ironic notifications

This patch adds an ironic_notifier that sends notifications to
external ironic endpoint /v1/events/. The events are triggered
by port updates, creation and deletion. Only ports with
vnic_type=baremetal are honored.

Story: 1304673
Co-Authored-By: Vladyslav Drok <vdrok@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: If15e1944c13052d1a14716c6d7fe46f7fdbe9a09

subject: Remove direct branching/tagging ACL for Chef
messages:
[{'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-08 14:20:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-08 16:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Under discussion with Samuel, DNM'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-20 14:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

I think the Chef team releases their artifacts using an external process, aligned with their consuming ecosystem, and as such should retain the direct tagging/branching rights they need to achieve that.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-08 14:20:13.000000000', 'message': "Remove direct branching/tagging ACL for Chef

The release process for official OpenStack components now uses
release requests using changes proposed to the openstack/releases
git repository. This allows peer review of release requests,
including version numbers, and run a series of checks to make
sure the release is likely to be successful once the tag is
pushed. The same process supports the creation of additional repo
branches as well. This all ensures that releases are reported
correctly on the releases.openstack.org website.

As a result of this process, nobody needs to push tags directly
or create branches directly. The Chef repositories actually never
used direct tagging/branching, so let's fix the ACLs there.

Change-Id: Idc99a60f4980ea7f2e98d224e46a84a3b8886e83
"}]
commit_message:
Remove direct branching/tagging ACL for Chef

The release process for official OpenStack components now uses
release requests using changes proposed to the openstack/releases
git repository. This allows peer review of release requests,
including version numbers, and run a series of checks to make
sure the release is likely to be successful once the tag is
pushed. The same process supports the creation of additional repo
branches as well. This all ensures that releases are reported
correctly on the releases.openstack.org website.

As a result of this process, nobody needs to push tags directly
or create branches directly. The Chef repositories actually never
used direct tagging/branching, so let's fix the ACLs there.

Change-Id: Idc99a60f4980ea7f2e98d224e46a84a3b8886e83

commit_message:
Switch to latest RDO repositories

The current-passed-ci repositories are the latest set of stable packages
from the current development cycle.  During release time, we'll need to
switch this to the upstream repositories once they are out (for example
switch this to the Rocky repositories in stable/rocky).

Depends-On: I6c800dcd5b3fc6f7cc1c1e0777d93ab40c6a5e09
Change-Id: Ie9c39a608aa9341e0b569431c5f7a595ea1ed374

commit_message:
Squash: exclude nested alloc cands in older microversions

This is a followon to explain [1] via code.  Rather than using any logic
to do with child providers, this filters out any allocation candidate
that involves more than one provider from the same tree.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565487/27/nova/api/openstack/placement/handlers/allocation_candidate.py@231

blueprint: nested-resource-providers-allocation-candidates

Change-Id: Ib3891b83feba8e010de1c71ee88e4c80d474ba9f

commit_message:
Support port binding extended attributes for querying port

Currently Port class does not have port binding extended attributes for
QueryParameters, so there is no way to filter using those properties.

Add those properties to QueryParameters to pass query validation so
that user can query using port binding attributes.

Change-Id: I48e4a2efce88f6e2c68ae63337a2cf5bb7303013

commit_message:
Switch to python3 for glance service

python2 will retire in sometime, so we should start
switch to python3. As there are no real consumers
for rpm-packaging services specs, so switching services
spec to python3 only.

- Also do not skip py3 while generating spec for glance.
- Switch to stestr
- Switch to sphinx-build for doc generation

Depends-On: I751aac4260b0583da53c9802d58e12556e122c82
Change-Id: I66c9f4e44d7ed7e60ee4a2b0b2a7366e1ca1fbfb

Add RDO mirror

Now that we actually have the latest RDO packages, use the mirror
hosted inside the OpenStack infrastructure.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-18 19:20:59.000000000', 'message': 'Extend Cinder pylint timeout

The pylint job in Cinder takes a long time, often resulting in
timeouts and the job being killed before it can actually complete.
This extends the timeout to give it more time to run.

Change-Id: I07e788c3bb7350e05df3391d5340ae4c0b58abd3
'}]
commit_message:
Extend Cinder pylint timeout

The pylint job in Cinder takes a long time, often resulting in
timeouts and the job being killed before it can actually complete.
This extends the timeout to give it more time to run.

Change-Id: I07e788c3bb7350e05df3391d5340ae4c0b58abd3

Still looking for comeback on this from first review:

I don't see

- supports_recreate
- supports_migrate_to_same_host"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-27 04:45:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 >

None of those things are capabilities that a flavor or image would require.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-27 22:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> None of those things are capabilities that a flavor or image would require.

Hm, I can see a flavor requiring the latter two.  Let me ask my resident capabilities experts.  edmondsw/esberglu?'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-03-29 12:21:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

you can make a case for anything ("I want to make this go on a host that will later allow me to resize on the same host") but I'm not sure any of those 3 things that efried mentioned are super likely to be needed. Could always be added later if a reason arises.

I would definitely leave off supports_recreate because a) that's misnamed (it's actually specific to evacuate) and b) it looks like all drivers support that because it's implemented in compute/manager rather than in a driver, so I'm not seeing why it's even a capability at all. I'm probably going to be proposing a patch to remove that soon.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-29 12:50:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Okay, I'm convinced we don't need the missing capabilities as traits.  Thanks for your patience, all."}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2018-03-30 05:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-03 22:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-04-19 08:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add compute capabilities traits

The virt driver API in nova has a capabilities dict that lists the
capabilities of the virt driver.

Based on the patch at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/538498/6, let's
try to standardize the relevant capabilities into a new
os_traits.compute module.

Change-Id: I77f2c4c696010dfe25d3282374dac702b08abaa6

commit_message:
Add a tempest test for the --all-tenants bug.

The test verifies that the entire topology is returned both
if queried as an admin user or if queried with the
--all-tenants flag

commit_message:
send a regular notification when locked flag changing

Watcher is a project for optimization, by migrating instances among hosts.
It builds a compute model at the begening, and update it by notifications.
When one instance is locked by end users, it is excepted to send a regular
notification from Nova, so Watcher will update its compute model and not
migrate the locked instances.

Change-Id: Ie3dc44403e85ec5fbb29354f517868e5715f80b1

commit_message:
[WIP] Add dirty hack until openshift-ansible catches up

We need to be able to disable the openvswitch service that
openshift-ansibles sets up on the provisioned nodes. The commit that
does it [1] was merged in the 3.9 branch but it is not yet available in
the latest openshift-ansible 3.9 rpm. This commit inlines the needed
patch and applies it to openshift-ansible if openshift-ansible is
installed and the patch applies cleanly.

This is obviously a temporary solution to move forward withe CI for
TripleO deploying OpenShift.

[1] https://github.com/openshift/openshift-ansible/commit/cc9858ea60

Change-Id: I86d5bfdf42237c7080fe00fb3bdfffad617184e7

commit_message:
Ensure that sysctl can be applied on containers

Some sysctl can be applied to containers, so we add a test
to prove our containers can do it.

Change-Id: I40e2f0af00d6d763efcbb07306791d3cd3feff0d
Fixes-Bug: #1685677

commit_message:
import newton-eol tags

Use "edit-deliverable import-eol-tag" to record the information about
all of the existing newton-eol tags.

Change-Id: Iff29f42ccb02b9eec69750858e51459e33bc226f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

[{'created': '2018-06-15 08:59:56.000000000', 'message': 'Activate memcached debug only when using MemcachedDebug param.

Do not activate it with Debug anymore.  We are now pushing memcached
log into stdout where they will be collected by journald.  When
activating debug, it will log there all the requests/replies to/from
memcached.  This will make the journal grows fast and clutter it
will (most of the time) useless information.

So if memcached debug is needed for some reason let the operator says
so explicitly.

This review removes a duplicate conditional as well.

commit_message:
Activate memcached debug only when using MemcachedDebug param.

Do not activate it with Debug anymore.  We are now pushing memcached
log into stdout where they will be collected by journald.  When
activating debug, it will log there all the requests/replies to/from
memcached.  This will make the journal grows fast and clutter it
will (most of the time) useless information.

So if memcached debug is needed for some reason let the operator says
so explicitly.

Change-Id: I85b6ca421d326c6e764fade66726407b905c796d

commit_message:
Domain `start` command accepts multiple domain names

This is a followup patch to [1] making the `start` command accepting
multiple domain names in the same way as `stop` command does.

Possible duplicate domain names given on the command line removed
to avoid runtime errors.

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/488874

Change-Id: I48987d01187e4b4878e5d501d263e958be4e7693

commit_message:
Fix functional tests gate

With commit 88f5e11d8bf[1], neutron plugs new ports as dead vlan. During
functional tests all the ports are untagged. So such tag should be
removed during functional testing.

Closes-Bug: #1777673

[1] I024bbbdf7059835b2f23c264b48478c71633a43c

Change-Id: I7b472b4a4f51fea473635fbd731a897e46af5eee

[{'created': '2018-06-15 22:00:08.000000000', 'message': 'Document single nic configuration for standalone

The standalone installation can be done on a single nic provided that 3
ip addresses are available.  The original docs have been updated to

commit_message:
Document single nic configuration for standalone

The standalone installation can be done on a single nic provided that 3
ip addresses are available.  The original docs have been updated to
describe the traditional 2 nic setup.

Change-Id: I16ef7a14ef2aafaa0d3212fe2af7b9f4f2c54023
Related-Blueprint: all-in-one

commit_message:
Remove validation workflow calls

These validations have moved to the tripleo-validations repo and are
now implemented in Ansible. Remove these calls from the client.

Change-Id: Id5c0692e3a1d3f551dcd55822de968ca8753a4eb
Implements: blueprint workflow-move-validations

commit_message:
Get providers directly from ORM to make startup take half as long

In a time of starting neutron with more than 100 loadbalancers this
reduces real from 37.819s to 13.978s.

Change-Id: I8659869220073fe73bb7d8624ea43d0c7f28d41d

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with check hyper-v

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/541435/2/ : FAILURE in 7h 51m 29s'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-02-09 08:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-02-09 08:39:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I assume you're working toward moving placement-specific files into their own root directory instead of being under the nova directory. Could we go ahead and start moving some of these?"}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-02-09 08:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27552, 'date': '2018-02-09 08:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2018-02-09 09:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-09 11:40:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> I assume you're working toward moving placement-specific files into
 > their own root directory instead of being under the nova directory.
 > Could we go ahead and start moving some of these?

That's not the immediate goal. Right now the goal is to centralize all the stuff in one common place to expose the issues and to explore what problems will arise when an eventual extraction happens.

When the extraction does happen it will be to an entirely separate repo/project, at which point being able to lift and shift the nova/api/openstack/placement dir in a fairly mechanical fashion (that preserves history) is desired (if possible).

In the meantime, however, we don't want to make it so that merging any of these intermediate changes has any impact on externally visible naming or packaging."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-02-09 15:39:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> That's not the immediate goal. Right now the goal is to centralize
> all the stuff in one common place to expose the issues and to
> explore what problems will arise when an eventual extraction
> happens.
> 
> When the extraction does happen it will be to an entirely separate
> repo/project, at which point being able to lift and shift the
> nova/api/openstack/placement dir in a fairly mechanical fashion
> (that preserves history) is desired (if possible).

totally agree... except that at that point the path would change to placement/api/openstack, right? So that nova is no longer in the path when it's no longer in the nova repo (and of course the goal being that placement not be specific to nova). So why not go ahead and start changing file paths accordingly even while still in the nova repo? That should help flush out the issues that will arise with extraction to a new repo. Not that you have to do that in this commit, but I'd start trying to do it bit by bit as you're touching things specifically to help flush things out.


> In the meantime, however, we don't want to make it so that merging
> any of these intermediate changes has any impact on externally
> visible naming or packaging.

Not sure I followed this. Some of the changes I've seen do include module path changes (e.g. nova.rc_fields) so I take it that's not what you mean, yet that's what I'm talking about, so...?"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-09 15:52:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> totally agree... except that at that point the path would change to
 > placement/api/openstack, right?

Probably just placement/. Part of the point/value in placement's design is that all of it is the API/service. (I recognize that this detail is not relevant to your point, just filling in some details for future reference).

 > So that nova is no longer in the
 > path when it's no longer in the nova repo (and of course the goal
 > being that placement not be specific to nova). So why not go ahead
 > and start changing file paths accordingly even while still in the
 > nova repo?

Because I want to preserve the option, in the interim, of merging some of these changes (which improve the footprint[1] of placement) without impacting packagers if things only get halfway. I'm not entirely certain what those impacts will always be, so figure being conservative and incremental is the way to go.

 > That should help flush out the issues that will arise
 > with extraction to a new repo. Not that you have to do that in this
 > commit, but I'd start trying to do it bit by bit as you're touching
 > things specifically to help flush things out.

I did some of that a long time ago[2] and since this is sort of a second go round, the incremental approach is a way to explore things in a less disruptive way.

[1] https://anticdent.org/placement-container-playground.html
[2] https://github.com/cdent/placement

 > Not sure I followed this. Some of the changes I've seen do include
 > module path changes (e.g. nova.rc_fields) so I take it that's not
 > what you mean, yet that's what I'm talking about, so...?

Module path changes within nova itself have less impact than adding an entirely new package.

It may make sense to do nova/placment/*.py at some point further down the stack, but like I've said before I'm trying to make the surface area of the changes smaller so they are more inspectable."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-02-09 20:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

got it, thanks'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-12 14:51:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-02-12 15:56:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-14115 : SUCCESS in 1h 01m 43s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-02-12 17:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/541435/3/ : SUCCESS in 2h 09m 04s'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-02-12 21:47:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-02-12 22:39:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-06 20:16:40.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Isolate placement database config

The placement database connection (which can use the same connection
string as the api database) needs to be managed from its own module so
that the nova db files are not imported as this eventually leads to
importing object-related and other code which the placement service does
not need.

The wsgi application is now responsible for initializing the database
configuration.

Fixtures and a small number of tests are updated to reflected the new
location of the placement engine.

Change-Id: I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77

'}, {'created': '2018-02-27 09:59:29.000000000', 'message': 'Isolate placement database config

The placement database connection (which can use the same connection
string as the api database) needs to be managed from its own module so
that the nova db files are not imported as this eventually leads to
importing object-related and other code which the placement service does
not need.

The wsgi application is now responsible for initializing the database
configuration.

Fixtures and a small number of tests are updated to reflected the new
location of the placement engine.

The original parse_args needed to import RPC and database related
modules that are not required in the placement context. A new
_parse_args method is added to wsgi.py which does the minimal required
work.

work.

Change-Id: I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77

commit_message:
Isolate placement database config

The placement database connection (which can use the same connection
string as the api database) needs to be managed from its own module so
that the nova db files are not imported as this eventually leads to
importing object-related and other code which the placement service does
not need.

The wsgi application is now responsible for initializing the database
configuration.

Fixtures and a number of tests are updated to reflected the new
location of the placement engine.

The original parse_args needed to import RPC and database related
modules that are not required in the placement context. A new
_parse_args method is added to wsgi.py which does the minimal required
work. Because we no longer use the central parse_args, the placement
db sync in nova/cmd/manager.py must make a manual configuration of the
context manager.

blueprint placement-extract

Change-Id: I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77

commit_message:
Don't heal allocations for deleted servers

InstanceList.get_by_filters by default returns deleted
servers, which we don't want to heal, so this adds the
missing filter along with a functional test to show
this working as expected.

Change-Id: Ic18b3ea5c7db5a0535488498b4e330803e0635b5
Closes-Bug: #1776743

commit_message:
allow setting tarball-base once in the repository-settings

Rather than requiring tarball-base be set every time in the release,
allow it to be set in the repository-settings section. The release
value acts as an override.

Change-Id: I48e424b9977a2acbfa46221da80ad0d698de8e88
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
bypass validation checks when tags exist

Create a decorator we can use to bypass checks when tags exist and
apply it to the validation functions that make sense.

Change-Id: I91a26abd2934b6a65ae1c1c15d125fd183cd4a23
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
make sphinxext support eol tags

Fix the sorting for EOL tags so when we collapse the release history
of a project to show it on the web site the sort works.

Also skip over the EOL tags when determining the "latest" release from
the branch. They are still displayed as part of the full tag history.

Change-Id: Iedde30f65bdfa89db0c6697ff031a75350090892
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 17:25:29.000000000', 'message': 'protect against errors from the hound API

When codesearch.o.o is re-indexing the API responds with something
that is not JSON. Rather than worry about all of the various errors we
could receive from an API that is only providing advisory information,
catch anything, log it, and proceed in a safe manner.

Change-Id: Ia910215029b3ece31db180396dbb50c82a7f3a59
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
protect against errors from the hound API

When codesearch.o.o is re-indexing the API responds with something
that is not JSON. Rather than worry about all of the various errors we
could receive from an API that is only providing advisory information,
catch anything, log it, and proceed in a safe manner.

Change-Id: Ia910215029b3ece31db180396dbb50c82a7f3a59
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-14 15:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-14 15:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

holding until I can coordinate the rest of this series with Tony'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-15 05:15:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> holding until I can coordinate the rest of this series with Tony

So I'd need to assemble a change (or series) at the end of this similar to the tripleo one to mark update all the EOL tags for newton.  I can do that.

IIUC it's [1] that prevents us from trying to tag/publish these deliverables which will be a little strange for series other than newton (well those in [2])  Do we need to think about extending that logic or is there something else that helps us that I missed


[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/roles/copy-release-tools-scripts/files/release-tools/process_release_requests.py#n137
[2] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/roles/copy-release-tools-scripts/files/release-tools/process_release_requests.py#n29"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-15 13:17:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > holding until I can coordinate the rest of this series with Tony
 > 
 > So I'd need to assemble a change (or series) at the end of this
 > similar to the tripleo one to mark update all the EOL tags for
 > newton.  I can do that.

Sure, we could do that. In fact, I'll give it a go today.

 > IIUC it's [1] that prevents us from trying to tag/publish these
 > deliverables which will be a little strange for series other than
 > newton (well those in [2])  Do we need to think about extending
 > that logic or is there something else that helps us that I missed

That logic prevents new tags and in newton branches, and more importantly stops us from recreating branches after we close them. We shouldn't need to update that logic as long as we stop deleting other branches. We could make it smarter to skip branch requests where an EOL tag is found, I guess. But we have a while before that should become an issue.

In the mean time, I will manually process the patch that adds the newton-eol tags for the TripleO deliverables, like I did with the release tags."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-19 14:36:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

I *think* this series is ready for review now. The final patch should have all of the newton eol tags as an example, and we can import the others if we want to do that as well.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-19 19:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-19 23:13:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-20 09:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
update validation to support eol tags

Update the version string validation to allow a series-eol
tag. Require that the EOL tag for a deliverable match the series and
be applied to all repositories that are part of the deliverable.

Extend the Release data object to understand whether its tag is an EOL
tag and if so to return the series component from it as eol_series.

Story: #2001879
Task: #14344
Change-Id: I40b6822c942b559dc6f18a4b6be6abb5407c4d7c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add cluster-modules to OSC

This change adds database support to the python-openstackclient
project for the cluster-modules command.

The trove command cluster-modules is now:
    openstack database cluster modules

Change-Id: Ib16578de1520163e9b9bc6894a079e8f0fcef37b
Partially-Implements: blueprint trove-support-in-python-openstackclient

subject: fix tox python3 overrides
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-07 16:47:02.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ie9d1d45811450e3feadd0dd3d027d3a20370f206
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ie9d1d45811450e3feadd0dd3d027d3a20370f206
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

handle duplicates.

subject: Putting context as the first parameter
messages:
[{'account_id': 28409, 'date': '2018-06-11 11:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-06-11 11:34:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-12 02:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks for your first contribution on Zun. There is a bunch of test failures. Possibly, it is due to that the context needs to be put as the first parameter in every callers of the format_container as well.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-12 02:24:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10206, 'date': '2018-06-12 11:19:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

You need to change the parameters at method call. revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-13 21:54:36.000000000', 'message': 'Be explicit about tox python version

We want to default all jobs to use python 3 except for
the ones that use explicit versions. Unfortunately, the
current tox behavior for setting basepython to python3
is not intuitive.

If the system default is python 3.5, then when basepython
is set to python3, both the py35 and py36 targets will
end up running with python 3.5.

To get around this we need to not set a default base
version and explicitly set each testenv to python3 that
we want to run using 3 instead of 2 but do not really
care which minor version is used.

Change-Id: I3971eeafbd1e732a584b0c52d2eb6c2175b709aa
'}]
commit_message:
Be explicit about tox python version

We want to default all jobs to use python 3 except for
the ones that use explicit versions. Unfortunately, the
current tox behavior for setting basepython to python3
is not intuitive.

If the system default is python 3.5, then when basepython
is set to python3, both the py35 and py36 targets will
end up running with python 3.5.

To get around this we need to not set a default base
version and explicitly set each testenv to python3 that
we want to run using 3 instead of 2 but do not really
care which minor version is used.

Change-Id: I3971eeafbd1e732a584b0c52d2eb6c2175b709aa

commit_message:
Delete unused files to increase test coverage

auth.py, client.py, fake_client.py are unused in manilaclient,
delete these files to increase the test coverage from 77% to 80%

Change-Id: I734b79f6aa24b4b002047c74a5ef76d19700f200

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-02-09 12:36:48.000000000', 'message': "Add detail=True query string to /nodes API endpoint

We currently support /nodes/detail as a API endpoint this does not fit
the RESTful and resourceful API design principles, of <resource
type>/<resource id> and makes it hard to consume the API from frameworks
that expect that structure. We can't remove the old endpoint so that is
safe guarded by the restricted node names list, this patch adds a
/nodes?detail=True query string to allow those consuming the API to use
the expected URL form.

Change-Id: I694919b4a4eaa3419318bbee1cde79de15e19afa
Closes-Bug: #1662921

commit_message:
Add detail=[True, False] query string to API list endpoints

We currently support /[nodes, ports, portgroups, chassis]/detail as an
API endpoint for getting a detailed list of each object. This does not
fit the RESTful and resourceful API design principles of <resource
type>/<resource id> and makes it hard to consume the API from frameworks
that expect that structure. We can't remove the old endpoint, so that is
safeguarded by the restricted node names list. This patch adds a
?detail=[True, False] query string to the list API endpoints to allow
those consuming the API to use the expected URL form.

Change-Id: I694919b4a4eaa3419318bbee1cde79de15e19afa
Story: #1662921
Task: #10176

tripleo deploy add test coverage for non default plan

I61763f62c5d44f098ad60f9426871caef16cd6de updated the existing test
but I forgot to add a test covering the case where a non-default
plan-environment is passed.

commit_message:
Switch to python3 for keystone service

python2 will retire in sometime, so we should start
switch to python3. As there are no real consumers
for rpm-packaging services specs, so switching services
spec to python3 only.

Also do not skip py3 while generating spec for keystone.

Change-Id: Id8eba4dcfa9652967993c41af9161bad8559b9fd

subject: Bug Fix : Tacker server can't restart when host reboot
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2874, 'name': 'yong sheng gong', 'email': 'gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net', 'username': 'gongysh'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 19644, 'name': 'Yan Xing an', 'email': 'yanxingan@cmss.chinamobile.com', 'username': 'yanxingan'}, {'_account_id': 22290, 'name': 'hyunsik Yang', 'email': 'yangun@dcn.ssu.ac.kr', 'username': 'hyunsikYang'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26222, 'name': 'Cong Phuoc Hoang', 'email': 'hoangphuocbk2.07@gmail.com', 'username': 'hoangphuoc'}, {'_account_id': 28174, 'name': 'Kim Bao Long', 'email': 'longkb@vn.fujitsu.com', 'username': 'longkb.fvl'}]

[{'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 03:59:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 05:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 05:54:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Not sure what's your intention but looks like you just reversed back the script."}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 05:56:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 05:58:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:02:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Just so you know, If you are using devstack setup, and after restarting your system if you want to retain the previous state of openstack then run ./rejoin-stack.sh in your terminal. This is the default design of devstack, not just tacker. Just starting tacker alone does not help.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:03:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sorry, the rejoin-stack.sh is not there anymore so I think the best think is to ./stack.sh'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Sorry, the rejoin-stack.sh is not there anymore so I think the best
 > think is to ./stack.sh

Thank you for your comment.

But, before review it, please test it first.

I already tested... please... review after testing...'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:13:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

After restarting the server, nothing works. My point is with your script, only tacker service start.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:15:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

FYI, Requiring a complete re-run of DevStack after a reboot has always
been intentional.'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:25:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> FYI, Requiring a complete re-run of DevStack after a reboot has
 > always
 > been intentional.
I don't think so.. your comment is wrong.

Current version of devstack is working well all of the service after reboot of host except Tacker. 

Almost devstack of openstack project register itself using systemctl enable. 
So, user can use openstack environment. 

BTW, did you test it first?

After testing, please review it."}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Hyunsik. Yes, I did test this. After rebooting the server, all the services do start but all the ovs network interfaces and bridge (virtual network interface that were mapped with the physical ones)disappeared.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:49:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Because of the test, I have to unstack and stack again my server.
You can try to run some of the tacker's commands and see (create VNF, VNFFG).

I understand that your patch fixes the service startup script but IMO, there's also work to do at the devstack level."}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Hi Hyunsik. Yes, I did test this. After rebooting the server, all
 > the services do start but all the ovs network interfaces and bridge
 > (virtual network interface that were mapped with the physical
 > ones)disappeared.

About that cases, if you add interface info into the network setup in linux. it will not disappears.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 06:54:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I know that but that feature should be done by the stack.sh script. If I have to do that manually myself, what's the point of stacking up?"}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 07:00:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I know that but that feature should be done by the stack.sh script.
 > If I have to do that manually myself, what's the point of stacking
 > up?

I didn't mean it....

Anyway.
This bug fix is for running of tacker server after reboot.
Currently, only tacker have problem about it.
IMO, if it is helps to other, i think it is a temporal solution.
i don't understand of your review. 
We found bug and it is not critical, but it is inconvenient.
So, i think that this is helps for others, anything is more necessary?
If you test it with this bugfix and have some problem, please let me know.."}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-11 08:39:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2018-05-11 09:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

What I mean is even if you can fix the tacker service startup script, devstack will not work after the reboot (of-course, tested many times). I have to unstack and stack anyway to make it work (I have to do it right now). I can never get the devstack works again after rebooting. And the fact is "DevStack is not intended to support restoring a running stack after a reboot." You can ask in the devstack channel. It's not my words.

Btw, not sure what you're trying to do in this new patch.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-29 16:41:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-30 01:39:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-30 02:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (2 comments)
Additionally, run_process included all of the function below. So, I will delete it.'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-05-30 02:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2018-05-30 16:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I tested this patch and it worked. I just -1 for waiting gate check.'}, {'account_id': 22290, 'date': '2018-06-01 12:08:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2018-06-06 08:17:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2018-06-07 04:47:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Bug Fix : Tacker server can't restart when host reboot

In the devstack, tacker server can't restart
when host reboot.

Therefore, this patch enable the tacker server to
the systemctl and restart it, using run_process in
devstack.

Change-Id: I2c40abc4cc5cae48e7e26a114b66f158b68e9464
Related-Bug: #1770542

commit_message:
[Doc] Add 'gateway' and 'mtu' in share network api-ref

The attributes "gateway" and "mtu" are already added in Shared File
Systems API since version 2.18 and 2.20. This patch provides description
about them in response parameters, and adds them to response examples.

Change-Id: I55e3a04453a9edd20b5ca4e1627ae8c3ae5601cc

[{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-16 22:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-17 02:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-17 18:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-17 19:05:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2018-06-18 12:28:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

@Hongbin, Thanks for that patch'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2018-06-18 12:33:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Seems that the gophercloud need to modify also. I will help to modify the response in golang client.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-19 02:46:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Seems that the gophercloud need to modify also. I will help to
 > modify the response in golang client.

Kevin, did the gophercloud is using the 'network_list' API?"}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2018-06-19 05:16:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > Seems that the gophercloud need to modify also. I will help to
 > > modify the response in golang client.
 > 
 > Kevin, did the gophercloud is using the 'network_list' API?

Don't use this API,
I wonder the address struct for capsule:
type Address struct {
	PreserveOnDelete bool    `json:"preserve_on_delete"`
	Addr             string  `json:"addr"`
	Port             string  `json:"port"`
	Version          float64 `json:"version"`
	SubnetID         string  `json:"subnet_id"`
}
Will it be changed?'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-06-19 15:52:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > > Seems that the gophercloud need to modify also. I will help to
 > > > modify the response in golang client.
 > >
 > > Kevin, did the gophercloud is using the 'network_list' API?
 > 
 > Don't use this API,
 > I wonder the address struct for capsule:
 > type Address struct {
 > PreserveOnDelete bool    `json:"preserve_on_delete"`
 > Addr             string  `json:"addr"`
 > Port             string  `json:"port"`
 > Version          float64 `json:"version"`
 > SubnetID         string  `json:"subnet_id"`
 > }
 > Will it be changed?

Don't think so. Only the response of network_list is changed. Other APIs are left untouched. The address structure should be the same as before.'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2018-06-20 05:11:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-16 22:33:07.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Improve the format of network_list

Change-Id: Id1e652d944be852697f18958899e395918ab0885
'}, {'created': '2018-06-17 02:03:06.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Improve the format of network_list

Change-Id: Id1e652d944be852697f18958899e395918ab0885
'}, {'created': '2018-06-17 18:57:45.000000000', 'message': "Introduce 'fixed_ips' to network_list

Modify the response of network_list API. Add a 'fixed_ips' field
that contains the list of IP addresses and their subnet IDs.
This change is primarily for aligning the format with nova and
neutron so that API consumers can use the same parsing code.
The first use case is from Heat. Heat would be able to use the
same code for parsing nova's interface_list and zun's network_list.

commit_message:
Introduce 'fixed_ips' to network_list

Modify the response of network_list API. Add a 'fixed_ips' field
that contains the list of IP addresses and their subnet IDs.
This change is primarily for aligning the format with nova and
neutron so that API consumers can use the same parsing code.
The first use case is from Heat. Heat would be able to use the
same code for parsing nova's interface_list and zun's network_list.

Change-Id: Id1e652d944be852697f18958899e395918ab0885

commit_message:
VNF/VNFFG/NS in PENDING_DELETE status can't be deleted correctly.

When resource's deletion process is interrupted by some reasons,
it stays in PENDING_DELETE status. We cannot find it from db with
_ACTIVE_UPDATE_ERROR_DEAD status. Resources include VNF, VNFFG,
and NS.

Change-Id: Iae7e0ac7629dbe3c5ce79aab3dd2300da8b78df2
Closes-bug: #1689426
Co-Authored-By: claire1006 <baofangyan@cmss.chinamobile.com>

[{'created': '2018-06-19 01:28:50.000000000', 'message': "[Unity] Return logged-out initiators

In current implementation, Unity driver doesn't return the targets which
connect to the logged-out initiators, which causes the zone manager
fails to clean up the FC zone.

The fix returns all the targets of specified initiators no matter they
are logged in or not.

Change-Id: I1438d0bd4a43e1813dfb0a6e9b3c4a177c2fee8f
Closes-bug: #1773305
(cherry picked from commit 1ef06d4a31c3010f170da20fcc823dd81e77c1a7)

The fix returns all the targets of specified initiators no matter they

commit_message:
[Unity] Return logged-out initiators

In current implementation, Unity driver doesn't return the targets which
connect to the logged-out initiators, which causes the zone manager
fails to clean up the FC zone.

The fix returns all the targets of specified initiators no matter they
are logged in or not.

Change-Id: I1438d0bd4a43e1813dfb0a6e9b3c4a177c2fee8f
Closes-bug: #1773305
(cherry picked from commit 1ef06d4a31c3010f170da20fcc823dd81e77c1a7)

commit_message:
Raise exception for PENDING_SCALE_IN state

This patch will help raise warning when users request scaling-in
in case of that the number of VNFs reach to the limited value.

Change-Id: Idf2cc69dd2c39e25b2eb3105b2f79155624debe8
Closes-Bugs: #1641646

commit_message:
database_stubs file cleanup

commit_message:
unable to create group from src in cinderclient

According the api schema of cinder, create_group_from_src
should only specify one of arguments from [group_snapshot_id, source_group_id].
Now cinderclient specified them both even if one of them is None.

This patch fix this issue to just pass one argument.

Change-Id: Idef51ab9a1452dd5eb3be4d4b6dca095a777d611
Closes-Bug: #1777555

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-12 17:21:34.000000000', 'message': 'Update to use oslo.messaging services for RPC and Notify

This introduces oslo.messaging variables that define the RPC and
Notify transports for the OpenStack services. These parameters replace
the rabbitmq values and are used to generate the messaging
transport_url for the service. The association of the messaging
backend server to the oslo.messaging services will then be transparent
to the octavia service.

This patch:
* Add oslo.messaging variable for RPC and Notify to defaults
* Update transport_url generation
* Add oslo.messaging to tests inventory
* Update tests
* Add release note

Change-Id: Ibfd9b5325bf89414439a1a516d1bbde0896904b5
'}]
commit_message:
Update to use oslo.messaging services for RPC and Notify

This introduces oslo.messaging variables that define the RPC and
Notify transports for the OpenStack services. These parameters replace
the rabbitmq values and are used to generate the messaging
transport_url for the service. The association of the messaging
backend server to the oslo.messaging services will then be transparent
to the octavia service.

This patch:
* Add oslo.messaging variable for RPC and Notify to defaults
* Update transport_url generation
* Add oslo.messaging to tests inventory
* Update tests
* Add release note

Change-Id: Ibfd9b5325bf89414439a1a516d1bbde0896904b5

'}, {'created': '2018-06-04 03:33:32.000000000', 'message': "Support websocket proxy for exec

In before, interactive exec works as following:
* Client makes an API call to server to request an interactive
  execution inside a container
* Server returns a URL that is an endpoint of the docker daemon
* Client connects to the docker's URL

This approach is considered to be unsecure because it directly
exposes docker API endpoint to end-users. This patch changes
the workflow to mitigate the security risk. The new workflow
is as following:
* Client makes an API call to server to request an interactive
  execution inside a container
* Server return a URL that is the websocket proxy server
* Clients connects to the proxy server
* The proxy server proxies the request to docker daemon

The proxy server will validate each incoming requests before
doing the proxy calls. The API endpoint of docker daemon will
be hidden from end-users.

Change-Id: I68e49b99eee9e6c22a9df2cc19a1d2ba5053489e
Partial-Bug: #1735076

commit_message:
Support websocket proxy for exec

In before, interactive exec works as following:
* Client makes an API call to server to request an interactive
  execution inside a container
* Server returns a URL that is an endpoint of the docker daemon
* Client connects to the docker's URL

This approach is considered to be unsecure because it directly
exposes docker API endpoint to end-users. This patch changes
the workflow to mitigate the security risk. The new workflow
is as following:
* Client makes an API call to server to request an interactive
  execution inside a container
* Server return a URL that is the websocket proxy server
* Clients connects to the proxy server
* The proxy server proxies the request to docker daemon

The proxy server will validate each incoming requests before
doing the proxy calls. The API endpoint of docker daemon will
be hidden from end-users.

Change-Id: I68e49b99eee9e6c22a9df2cc19a1d2ba5053489e
Partial-Bug: #1735076

[{'created': '2018-06-13 21:20:03.000000000', 'message': "Ignore UserWarning for scope checks during test runs

Placement API policy rules are defaulting to system scope.
Scope checks are disabled by default in oslo.policy, but
if you hit the API with a token that doesn't match the scope,
it generates a UserWarning, for every policy check on that
request. This is pretty annoying, so just filter those warnings
during our test runs.

Change-Id: I30ed00a96390d2c76cfc2a40c5a47c16eb51711c
"}]
commit_message:
Ignore UserWarning for scope checks during test runs

Placement API policy rules are defaulting to system scope.
Scope checks are disabled by default in oslo.policy, but
if you hit the API with a token that doesn't match the scope,
it generates a UserWarning, for every policy check on that
request. This is pretty annoying, so just filter those warnings
during our test runs.

Change-Id: I30ed00a96390d2c76cfc2a40c5a47c16eb51711c

'}, {'created': '2018-06-03 22:52:06.000000000', 'message': "Add exec_instances to data model

Zun is going to implement a proxy for interactive execute.
The first step is to introduce data model for tracking each
exec instances of a container. An exec instance in Zun is
an one-to-one mapping for exec instance in Docker.
We will use it to track a docker's exec instance as well as
a generated token for granting access of this exec instance.
In the future, the websocket proxy will retrieve the token from
incoming request and match it to the one stored in DB.
The request will be rejected if the token doesn't match.

This patch introduces the data model of exec_instance
in DB api and objects layer. It basically contains three
fields: container_id, exec_id, token. The container_id
is the id of the container record in Zun. The exec_id
is the ID of the docker's exec instance. The token is
as described above.
